metadata.case_name: Inamdars of Wanz and Dindoli v. State (Civil Appeals Nos. 1048-1050 of 1963)

facts.text: Appellants held shares in the inam village of Wanz and some in that of Dindoli.
Inams granted in 1794 and 1803 respectively; nature depends on sanad or terms of grant.
High Court held on construction of sanads that inams were grants of villages with exemption from land revenue, conveying soil and rights over trees, water, mines etc.
Survey introduced in villages in 1900 under Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879; amounts payable by tenants to inamdars assessed under the Code.

Under S.216 of Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879, settlement introduced in both villages at different times; after survey, inferior holders liable to pay land revenue assessed to inamdar instead of variable rent.
Appellants moved Bombay High Court by petitions under Arts. 226 and 227 for quashing decision of Bombay Revenue Tribunal on compensation; High Court disposed by common judgment dated September 1958.
Inams abolished by Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, 1952; all inam villages/lands liable to land revenue under S.5.
Inferior holders: persons claiming through tillers in possession at time of grant; rights to possession intact, inamdars entitled to rents/assessments.
Collector asked appellants to produce evidence for claims on right to forfeit tenancies and reversion; appellants failed to do so, no instance cited.
Grantees exempt from land revenue not only for lands held by inferior holders but also lands in own possession or held by persons through them.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellants entitled to compensation under S.17(1) Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, 1952 for loss of assessment payable by inferior holders, or barred by S.17(5).
Nature of inams: grants of villages with exemption from land revenue (S.2(1)(e)(i)) or grants of land revenue only (S.2(1)(e)(ii)).
Whether compensation payable for loss of right to forfeit inferior holders' tenancies and right of reversion.

petitioner_arguments.text: Inams were grants of land revenue only, not villages exempt from revenue; thus S.17(5) does not apply.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.2(1)(e)(ii), S.17(5) Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, 1952

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if grants of villages exempt from revenue, not claiming on ground that villages made subject to revenue; loss due to inferior holders now paying to Government, not appellants.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.5 Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, 1952; S.17(1)

petitioner_arguments.text: After survey under Bombay Land Revenue Code, payments by tenants were land revenue.
Right to recover assessment from inferior holders lost not due to subjection to revenue but directly by Act; entitled under S.17(1).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.17(1) Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, 1952

petitioner_arguments.text: Rights of reversion and forfeiture taken away without compensation.

respondent_arguments.text: Inams were grants of villages partially exempt from land revenue; bar of S.17(5) applies.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.2(1)(e)(i), S.17(5) Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, 1952

respondent_arguments.text: Loss of assessment from inferior holders due to lands made subject to full revenue under S.5; claim barred by S.17(5).

court_reasoning.text: Sanads convey soil and rights over trees etc.; inams are grants of villages exempt from revenue, not mere land revenue grants.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellants' contention that pre-grant tenants paid revenue to government idle; no evidence of prior tenants; post-grant payments were rent, not revenue.

court_reasoning.text: Survey fixed assessment but did not alter nature; inamdar remained grantee of soil, exempt from revenue; tenant paid rent/assessment to inamdar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between grant of village exempt from revenue and grant of revenue only preserved in S.2(1)(e).

court_reasoning.text: Loss of right to assessment from inferior holders occasioned by lands subjected to revenue under S.5(2)(b); inferior holders now pay to government; claim barred by S.17(5).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Inamdar's exemption enabled retention of assessment; subjection to revenue causes loss.

court_reasoning.text: No distinction intended between lands in own possession and those of inferior holders for compensation under S.17(5).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Loss nil if right not abolished, as would collect and pay identical amount to government.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence produced for loss of forfeiture/reversion rights; impossible to value.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellants failed to cite instances or furnish material.

court_reasoning.text: Survey settlement did not confer occupant status on inferior holders or make them pay revenue to government; continued as inferior holders paying to inamdar.

holdings.text: Inams were grants of villages with partial exemption from land revenue under S.2(1)(e)(i); bar of S.17(5) applies to claim for loss of assessment from inferior holders.
No compensation for loss of reversion/forfeiture rights due to lack of evidence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary of State for India v. Shantaram Naravan
precedents_cited.relevance: Grants of inam lands may include right to mines or mineral products, preserved by S.9.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Abolished inams, subjected lands to revenue, barred certain compensation claims, provided for others.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879
statutes_cited.relevance: Introduced survey settlement; fixed assessments payable by inferior holders to inamdars.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petitions under 226/227; no argument on unconstitutionality raised.

outcome.summary: Appeals against Bombay High Court judgment dismissing writ petitions challenging denial of compensation by Revenue Tribunal dismissed; no compensation awarded for claimed losses.

key_quotes.text: "The appellants' contention would in effect wipe out this distinction and cannot therefore be accepted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects equation of village grants with revenue grants.

key_quotes.text: "The loss consequential on the abolition of the right to recover assessment is, therefore, nil."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why no compensable loss from inferior holders' assessments.

key_quotes.text: "No compensation can, therefore, be assessed or awarded for the loss of these rights."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: On lack of evidence for reversion/forfeiture claims.
